Content:

Author: bprater
Content: Come on -- this is Hacker News, not reddit.

Author: halo
Content: The downside is if their website design is anything to go by, it'll be as ugly as sin and have severe usability issues.

Author: edw519
Content:
The fact that their own web page doesn't render on every major browser or at every standard resolution screans louder than anything they say on it.

If you disqualify "laggards" as prospects, maybe you don't deserve to succeed.

And if you think that servicing one type of customer is at the expense of another, maybe you're not yet senior enough to be my vendor.

ADDENDUM:

Why is it that my hardest learned business lessons get downmodded so quickly? Who here is such a good hacker that they could afford to leave money on the table?

Author: joeguilmette
Content: rather than giving ppl with 250+ an option to change the bar at the top of the page, why dont they give those users the ability to downmod submissions?

Author: a-priori
Content: Thanks, but no thanks. "Atheist" works just fine for me.

Author: joeguilmette
Content: can you hear the seams of the bubble straining?

Author: bprater
Content: Maybe there are 5 people on the team. That gets it down to $80/hr.

Author: wallflower
Content:
How do independent Facebook application developers compete against the 800-lb gorillas of Facebook, Slide and RockYou? Slide and RockYou seem to prove economies of scale. From Craig Ulliot - developer of 50K+ daily user FB application 'Where I've been'

"Well my application has become incredibly popular, and I'm very excited about it, don't get me wrong!

But I'm a freelance developer, not a company, and its put a powerful 4GB $450 a month dedicated server on 3 backbones at maximum load and is pushing 2000GB a month in traffic. It doesn't make me any money and I'm getting hundreds of comments and emails daily about it.

How can i support it and maintain it? What do i do with it now? its growing at a few users a second, so should i get another server each month?"

http://tinyurl.com/yu6k98

Author: mig
Content: Very impressive. Is it just css or did you use any images etc.? Are you a designer?

Author: wallflower
Content: I wonder what the profit-margin for a top-100 Facebook application might be after paying for bandwidth/server costs, assuming they monetize through displaying advertising.

Author: ivankirigin
Content:
800x600 is below the "industry standard". To design for people with resolution that low is to cater to laggards at the expense of the vast majority.

But if you're on a mobile device, the issue is much more complicated obviously, and you get a pass :)

Author: wallflower
Content: Assuming they are working day and night, night and day that is close to $417/hr. The aspect of hiring high-class code hookers (or if you find that offensive, Ruby on Rails ninjas) aside, building a successful web site seems to be more about your network's influence when you launch.
